item.title: Where to Get Birthright in Baldur's Gate 3
item.description:
Some of the biggest ways to make your character better in Baldur's Gate 3 are to boost their base attributes. You can increase those attributes by picking the right feats, but outside of those, you'll mostly be limited in raising base attributes.

Outside of one-off situations you'll randomly come across, gear will be a major way you can increase the base attributes. While you'll often want to equip the best-looking armor to stay alive in combat, there are some gear pieces that may not look battle-ready, but can offer bonuses in combat depending on your class. Here's how to get Birthright, along with the best classes to equip it on.

Where to Get Birthright in Baldur's Gate 3

Players can only get Birthright in Act 3 upon entering the main city of Baldur's Gate. You can go and get the hat right away by heading to Sorcerous Sundries . The Birthright hat can be purchased from the person behind the front desk, either Rolan if you saved him and he made it to Baldur's Gate, or Lorroakan's Projection. No matter who is behind the desk, you can buy the hat for 1,025 Gold.

You can try and lower the prices by increasing your relationship with the merchant.

Depending on what you've done in Act 3 in regards to the Nightsong and Lorroakan, Rolan may stop selling to you. If this happens, your only chance of getting Birthright is either pickpocketing it off of him or killing him and looting it , though both of these options can be very dangerous.

Best Class/Character to Give Birthright to in Baldur's Gate 3

  • Charisma +2 (up to 22)

By far, the best character or class to give this hat to is a Warlock or Bard . If you have Wyll in your party and your character is neither, he's the best party member option. Not only does this help him pass Charisma checks, but the Agonising Blast feat adds the Charisma multiplier only on the damage of your Eldritch Blasts, which should be one of his best actions in battle.

Depending on your build, some Paladin or Sorcerer characters can get a good bonus from this hat, but Bard or Warlock is far superior across the board.

If you have already maxed out someone's charisma, this hat will boost it to 22, making your Charisma modifier +6 . Since headgear doesn't determine AC, this hat is a great option for a character focusing on dealing more damage.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: What to Do With Sparking Stones in Shadow Labyrinth
item.description:
Like almost every metroidvania before it, Shadow Labyrinth contains numerous collectible items for the player to discover. As you make your way through the game, one of the most common collectibles you encounter will be the Sparking Stones. However, like many of the elements in Shadow Labyrinth, there is very little direction or hand-holding when it comes to knowing what to do with these special stones. In this guide, we'll show you how to find and where to take the Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth.

Where to Take Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth

Progress to the Land of the Fugitives:

Before you can do anything with your Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth, you'll need to reach Bosconian Village in the Land of the Fugitives . To reach this region, you'll have to pass through the following areas:

  • Remote Prison
  • Barren Volcano
  • Sky-High Tree
  • Torn Lands
  • Giant Black Tower
  • Land of the Fugitives

Once you reach the village, you'll meet the Chief , and her daughter, Anpulane. Anpulane is the NPC that collects Sparkling Stones, but you will not be able to offer the stones to her when you first meet. You'll need to complete the duel with Thebe, then set off into the Forbidden Lands in search of the Spark-Bit and Dimension Warp Capsule .

Once you leave Bosconian Village and enter the Forbidden Lands, you can return to Anpulane and turn in the stones. Turning in the stones will earn you a total of five rewards, each given at a specific milestone. The final reward is given after turning in 98 Sparkling Stones , which may be the total number of Sparkling Stones found in the world.

Anpulane is found in Bosconian Village's throne room. Enter the chamber directly left of the Bosconian Village Miku Sol. Inside, you'll find Anpulane standing in front of the throne. Speak to her to initiate the process of returning the stones.

Sparkling Stone Rewards:

Sparking Stones

Reward

10

Map Marker Set

30

Heavy Armor Perk

50

Perk Capacitor

70

HP Tank

98

Anpulane's Gift

How to Get Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth

Collectibles & Combat:

There are two main methods of finding Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth. The first method, which accounts for the vast majority of locations, is through simple explorations. Shadow Labyrinth features two main collectible types: Red Crystals and Yellow Crystals. Red Crystals contain all the Max HP & ESP upgrades, High-Grade Materials – essentially all gameplay-related items.

Yellow Crystals are your typical non-essential collectibles. Many of these will be lore tablets, and unfortunately, there is no way to tell before picking one up. This is important, because Yellow Crystals also have the potential to be Sparkling Stones. You can begin finding Sparkling Stones as soon as you begin exploring, but there is no real reason to begin looking for them in earnest until you unlock ACTIV Shot, Double-Jump, and ESP Quake. All of these abilities are acquired before or just after gaining access to Bosconian Village. With those three abilities, you'll be able to reach all locations in the game.

The second method of acquiring Sparkling Stones in Shadow Labyrinth revolves around special combat encounters. Like many metroidvania games, Shadow Labyrinth features locked combat chambers, which force you to defeat every enemy before you can leave. While it is quite rare, every once in a while you'll receive a reward for completing a combat chamber, which is often a Sparking Stone.

You can also find Sparkling Stones by killing the special sparkling flying robots. These are almost always found tucked away in small, hidden chambers. These enemies are usually impervious to sword attacks. You must use ESP Actions , such as ESP Blast or ESP Grenade, to defeat them. Once you defeat them, use the GAIA's Devour mechanic. M ake sure you save enough ESP to use Devour, or you will miss your chance to get the stone.

These are currently all the methods of acquiring Sparkling Stones that we have discovered so far. If we discover anymore, we'll add them here.

item.title: 8 Games Every Gaming PC Owner Needs in Their Collection
item.description:
Summary

  • Gaming PCs provide top-notch performance; PC players love creative mods and tweaking settings.
  • Some of the best PC games offer optimized gameplay experiences and unforgettable moments.
  • Cyberpunk 2077, despite a rocky launch, shines on high-end PCs, offering an emotionally compelling journey with tons of replay value.

A gaming PC is a wise investment for players who want to enjoy games on cutting-edge hardware without any restrictions brought over by consoles. Tweaking settings to improve performance may seem like a chore, but it is something that many PC players relish.

Some of the most important and beloved PC games are well-optimized to run on this platform and are must-plays in the eyes of many. From technical marvels to graphical powerhouses, these are beloved games that almost every PC player should add to their collection — if they're not already there, of course!

1 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

CD Projekt Red's Magnum Opus is in a Class of its Own

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt
9 /10
53
9.5 /10
Released
May 19, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red
Publisher(s)
CD Projekt Red
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

The fact that CD Projekt Red has recently come out to comment on changing their approach to support both console and PC development in equal measure after focusing on the latter for a long time makes it clear why The Witcher 3 is such a prominent game on computers.

Players love pushing the visuals of this game to the max while also using mods to personalize the experience. It makes for a great time as players enjoy what is arguably the best platform to experience Geralt's final journey on.

2 Half-Life 2

Valve's Must-Play FPS Needs No Introduction

Half-Life 2
13
9.5 /10
Released
November 16, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Valve
Publisher(s)
Valve
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox 360, Xbox (Original), PS3, macOS, Linux, Android
Powered by

Valve has been hailed by many as champions of PC gaming, and titles like Half-Life 2 prove this in spades. Players loved the groundbreaking physics engine of this game, which is still mind-blowing to this day.

Using the Gravity Gun and exploring Ravenholm are just a few of the many ways this title stands out. PC players love how fun this game is to play, with new fans understanding why the demand for Half-Life 3 is still so strong.

3 Cyberpunk 2077

Players With High-End PCs Can Push This Game's Visuals to New Heights

6 Images
6 Images
Cyberpunk 2077
6 /10
110
8.9 /10
Released
December 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch 2, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the greatest video games ever made, which overcame its poor launch to wow the masses. It helped that CD Projekt Red released update after update to support this game following its release, making up for false promises and adding new content that spruces up the game in meaningful ways.

From an active modding community to the addition of Overdrive mode, there's no reason why PC players won't love what Cyberpunk 2077 brings to the table. It helps that V's emotional journey is so compelling that fans won't mind clocking in multiple playthroughs for this amazing video game.

4 The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

With Mods, This Game Becomes Something Truly Special

6 Images
6 Images
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim

Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong

Skyrim is an open-world title so popular that it needs no introduction. The fact that this game's modding community is still releasing curated content for Skyrim proves just how magical the experience is.

Players love role-playing as the Dragonborn and embarking on the journey of a lifetime in this game. Smashing enemies to a pulp and completing an array of memorable side quests feels great on PC, which is the most natural platform for this gargantuan open-world RPG.

5 Fallout: New Vegas

A Passionate Community Ensures That This One-of-a-Kind RPG is Infinitely Playable

Fallout: New Vegas
8 /10

Fallout: New Vegas is one of the greatest video games ever made that fans can't get enough of to this day. The role-playing opportunities in this title are off the charts, eventually turning New Vegas into a modern classic after its bugs and glitches were mostly done away with.

To enjoy the optimal New Vegas experience, players should download a ton of mods to optimize the game and modernize the gameplay. Curated mod lists like Viva New Vegas are a must to enjoy the game at its peak, letting fans get immersed in a role-playing masterpiece that is full of meaningful choices and consequences.

6 Baldur's Gate 3

Arguably the Greatest Modern RPG That Immerses Players in its Fantastical World

Baldur's Gate 3

Baldur's Gate 3 is a CRPG first, making it clear why PC is the best platform for this title. Fans will love the epic journey that Larian takes them on as they try to deal with the parasite currently invading their character's mind.

It's a massive RPG full of dozens of branching paths for players to uncover, even if Act 3 can be a bit frustrating for players to get through. Even then, this won't stop PC players from investing 200+ hours in their first playthrough before using mods to spice up the experience.

7 Minecraft

A Massive Indie Success That Places No Limits on a Player's Creativity

Minecraft is easily the biggest indie success that highlighted the prominence of this growing sector of gaming, eventually leading to Microsoft acquiring this game for a cool $2.5 billion in 2014.

Minecraft is available on every platform, but most players agree that PC is the best place to experience this iconic video game. Crafting with friends and letting their creativity run wild is just one of the many ways this revolutionary title can allow players to run wild with their imagination.

8 Portal 2

One of the Best Puzzle Games Ever Made

Portal 2

Many people hail Portal 2 as one of the greatest puzzle games ever made. The simple mechanics of creating portals, coupled with fun storytelling and unique improvements over the first title, ensure that fans will have a blast with this charming title.

Both the single-player campaign and multiplayer mode are great and worth checking out for fans of engaging puzzle games. Portal 2 is a blast to play on PC and ensures that players will have a fun time solving brain-teasers, while also checking out the wealth of custom content released for this title. Every PC gamer should have Portal 2 in their collection. If they don't, it should be at the top of the wishlist.

item.title: 7 Best Open-World Games With Satisfying Progression, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Horizon Forbidden West prioritizes deliberate exploration and character growth, making every upgrade feel earned.
  • Marvel's Spider-Man rewards players with momentum-based combat, customizable suits, and evolving traversal.
  • Dying Light transforms players from wimps to agile wall-runners through skill upgrades and gear improvements.

Open-world games tend to flood players with a map full of question marks, a to-do list longer than a tax audit, and the vague hope that things will start to feel worth it eventually. But some games know exactly how to reward curiosity, make each step feel earned, and turn every upgrade into a small personal victory.

These aren’t just open worlds to get lost in—they’re systems built to make players feel like they’re genuinely growing, changing, and mastering something. From smooth traversal upgrades to combat skills that snowball into chaos, here are the games that absolutely nail that addictive sense of progress.

7 Horizon Forbidden West

Climbing Feels Better When You Earn It

Horizon Forbidden West
9 /10
32
8.4 /10
Released
February 18, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood, Language, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
Guerrilla Games
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5
Powered by

It takes about ten minutes in Horizon Forbidden West to realize this isn’t just a prettier rehash of Zero Dawn . The sequel doesn’t just open up its world; it makes exploring it feel more deliberate. Players start out grounded—literally—relearning how to survive, scavenge, and fight. But by the time Aloy is gliding off mountaintops, diving into underwater ruins, and overriding giant robot snakes with a souped-up spear, the growth is tangible.

Progression isn’t dumped in the lap. Skills have to be chosen with intent across multiple trees, gear must be upgraded with parts from increasingly difficult machine types, and some traversal tools—like the Shieldwing and Pullcaster—have to be earned through story. The Western wilds are full of places that taunt the player early on, unreachable ledges and locked doors that practically laugh until the right tool or override is unlocked. And nothing beats the feeling of coming back hours later, fully kitted out, and finally cracking them open.

6 Marvel’s Spider-Man

Power Comes With Practice (And Cool Suits)

Marvel's Spider-Man
9.0 /10
Released
September 7, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Drug Reference, Language, Mild Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Insomniac Games
Platform(s)
PS4, PS5, PC
Powered by

Swinging across Manhattan doesn’t just feel good in Marvel’s Spider-Man —it feels better the longer players stick with it. The upgrade system leans into momentum, rewarding aggressive play and fluid combos with gadgets that multiply options mid-fight. There’s a rhythm to the combat that gets more complex and satisfying with each ability unlocked, especially when it starts to resemble a perfectly choreographed brawl from the comics.

But the real juice is in the suits. Each one comes with a unique power and can be mixed and matched with different mods to suit different playstyles. From web blossom finishers to spider-bro drone assists, everything starts to feel tailored by the endgame. Even side content feeds into this progression loop—research stations, challenge tokens, and enemy hideouts all offer meaningful rewards instead of just clutter. And somehow, the traversal, which feels incredible on hour one, still manages to evolve by hour twenty with moves like Point Launch boosts that turn the skyline into a playground.

5 Dying Light

From Wimp To Wall-Runner

Dying Light
7 /10
12
9.1 /10
Released
January 27, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Techland
Platform(s)
PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, PC
Powered by

Nobody starts out feeling cool in Dying Light . Aiden barely survives his first few chases, scrambles up ledges like he skipped leg day, and swings a pipe around like a drunk in a bar fight. But that’s the point. The parkour system doesn’t just exist—it develops. Stamina upgrades, skill unlocks, and movement tech like wall running and vault kicks completely transform how players interact with rooftops and alleyways.

By the time grappling hooks and paraglider upgrades enter the mix, traversal feels like second nature. Players go from clinging to ledges in fear to vaulting across districts in a single flow, even during nighttime when the Volatiles come out to play. The satisfaction comes from mastering a city that initially tries to kill the player at every corner. It’s not just skill trees doing the heavy lifting either—survivor rank, inhibitor collectibles, and gear rarity all play their part in making the world more manageable, one rooftop at a time.

4 Assassin’s Creed Odyssey

Nothing Says Progress Like Being Overleveled In A Toga

Assassin's Creed Odyssey
17
8.7 /10
Released
October 15, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Ubisoft Quebec
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC, Stadia
Powered by

Assassin’s Creed Odyssey doesn’t exactly hide how much it wants players to grind. But unlike earlier entries, it makes that grind feel like conquering an entire nation, one fort at a time. The leveling system is front and center, with each new tier of gear bringing with it perks, engravings, and those addictive little stat boosts that shave seconds off an assassination or add flair to a Spartan kick.

Exploration feeds directly into growth. Every cave, island, and fort holds something useful, whether it’s an ancient engraving or a boss encounter that drops legendary loot. Even the mercenary system adds a twist to progression, letting players climb their own little bounty hunter ladder with tangible benefits for doing so. The world opens up because the player earns it, both narratively and mechanically. And it helps that Kassandra (or Alexios) ends up feeling like a demigod by the time they’re done stabbing cultists and diving off statues of Zeus.

3 Elden Ring

Getting Lost Is A Skill Tree In Disguise

Elden Ring
10 /10
67
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
From Software
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, Xbox Series X
Powered by

There’s no quest log pointing the way in Elden Ring , no friendly waypoint saying, “go here for cool loot.” But that’s what makes its progression feel earned. Every boss beaten, every crypt looted, every dragon torched to death in some misty swamp was likely found by accident, and that randomness is part of what makes leveling up feel satisfying.

Stat points aren’t just numbers here. They reshape the playstyle. A few more points in Dexterity, and a new katana becomes viable. Invest in Mind, and suddenly Spirit Ashes don’t die in ten seconds. And once legacy dungeons like Stormveil Castle are tackled, players get a sense of just how far they’ve come from dying to dogs in Limgrave. Even the way the map unfolds is part of the progression. Players might ride east expecting a new biome, only to end up in hellish Caelid with rotting monsters and no easy way back. Surviving that? That’s progress.

2 Ghost Of Tsushima

Mastery Looks Like Poetry In Combat

Ghost of Tsushima
9 /10
42
8.9 /10
Released
July 17, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language, Partial Nudity
Developer(s)
Sucker Punch
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5
Powered by

At first, Jin Sakai is a samurai with a code and a katana. By the end of Ghost of Tsushima , he’s a one-man army who can mow down an entire Mongol camp without taking a scratch. But progression here isn’t just mechanical—it’s woven into the story. Jin’s shift from honorable warrior to calculated ghost is reflected in every skill tree branch and armor upgrade.

Players unlock new stances to counter specific enemy types, ghost weapons that complement stealth, and charms that subtly shape how Jin behaves in combat. But perhaps the most satisfying part is the Legend of the Ghost system. As Jin’s fame spreads, enemies become terrified, battles change before they begin, and even duels start to feel different. The island evolves with him. Fog clears from the map as shrines are visited and foxes are followed, each upgrade another step toward restoring Tsushima—or burning it down in style.

1 The Legend Of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild

Curiosity Is The Best Skill Tree

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
10 /10
46
9.2 /10
Released
March 3, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E for Everyone: Fantasy Violence, Use of Alcohol, Mild Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Nintendo EPD
Platform(s)
Nintendo Wii U, Nintendo Switch, Nintendo Switch 2
Powered by

Breath of the Wild never hands out power in the traditional sense. There’s no XP bar to fill or passive stat tree to grind through. Instead, the progression is environmental. Players get stronger by climbing higher, lasting longer, solving trickier shrine puzzles, and learning the rules of a world that quietly punishes impatience and rewards experimentation.

Link starts with little more than an old man’s hoodie and a stick, but it’s not long before he’s launching himself across Hyrule with bomb jumps and paragliding off the backs of dragons. The Great Plateau teaches the fundamentals, but beyond that, everything is optional—and that freedom is what makes the progression so compelling. Whether it’s learning how to shield surf off a mountaintop or discovering how to use metal boxes as makeshift weapons in a thunderstorm, the world itself becomes the upgrade system. And nothing feels more satisfying than solving a puzzle not because it was marked on a map, but because a broken-down ruin caught the player’s eye.

item.title: How to Get High-Grade Material in Shadow Labyrinth
item.description:
As you upgrade your main weapon and ESP (stamina) in Shadow Labyrinth, you'll quickly hit a wall when you see you need to acquire High-Grade Material. This powerful crafting item is incredibly useful, but also exceedingly rare. On top of this, for much of Shadow Labyrinth' s early-to-mid-game, you'll have no idea where to find it. In this guide, we'll show you how to find High-Grade Material in Shadow Labyrinth, and provide you with the first two locations, which will allow you to upgrade both your sword, and your max ESP .

How to Get High-Grade Material in Shadow Labyrinth

Progress Into the Forbidden Lands:

In Shadow Labyrinth, you can upgrade your sword and ESP (stamina) at the Miku Sol save points – essentially this game's version of the soulslike bonfire. While accessing the Miku Sol, you'll find the upgrades under the Enhance menu. At the start, you'll only be able to access the sword and ESP upgrades, which will only require Ora for the first three levels.

However, once you reach the level 4 upgrades in both categories, you'll see that you need one High-Grade Material to progress. High-Grade Material will be required to perform every fourth upgrade . Unlike other crafting materials in Shadow Labyrinth, High-Grade Material is not collected from enemies. Instead, they take the form of red crystal collectibles, just like the HP Capacitor (Max Health upgrade), and the HP Tank charges. Unfortunately, this means that when you see a red crystal hidden or tucked away on the map, you won't know what it is until you collect it. This will require a huge amount of exploration if you do not know where to look. Luckily, we can give you a head start.

To begin with, don't expect to find any High-Grade Material until you reach the Forbidden Lands. If there are any earlier, they are blocked by obstacles that you will not be able to pass until you unlock abilities after the Forbidden Lands. You'll reach the Forbidden Lands after passing through the first several regions, and locating the first major town at Bosconian Village in the Land of the Fugitives .

High-Grade Material Location 1:

The first High-Grade Material we encountered was located in the Door to the Abyss region. You'll pass through this area not directly after leaving Bosconian Village in the Land of the Fugitives, and entering the Forbidden Lands. After making your way west through the long, slender section of the map, the Door to the Abyss area will open up into a long rectangular section.

You'll have the ACTIV Shot (Grapple) and Midair Dodge abilities unlocked at this point, which will both be required to collect the first High-Grade Material.

The first High-Grade Material is located near the eastern edge of this section. After Puck stops to mention Sheyenne GAIA, you'll know you are just about to enter the desired region. Pass through the first chamber screen, then as you enter the second, you'll see the red crystal collectible. You'll need to head west on the lower path, until you reach the checkpoint seen in the above video. From the checkpoint, head back east on the upper path, then drop to the lower sections to collect the material. Be careful, as this section is packed with dangerous foes.

High-Grade Material Location 2:

The second High-Grade Material in Shadow Labyrinth is located in the Crystalline Palace . This area is directly west of the Door to the Abyss, and is part of the normal progression in the Forbidden Lands . This region is much larger than the previous, so it may take a bit longer to reach your destination if you are returning to the area.

You'll want to make your way along the northern edge of the region, until you reach the third chamber from the northwest corner. In this chamber you'll find a multi-leveled area with a waterfall that falls through the middle. You'll need to make your way to the top level of this section, then follow the correct path through the water to reach the rec crystal collectible that represents the High-Grade Material. See the map, and the video, for the exact location.

As we discover more High-Grade Material locations, we will add them here.
